> -----Original Message-----
> From: Bryce Fischer [mailto:bryce@...]
[...]
> I have a function that all it does is take a message body, and set of
> parameters (i.e., recipient list, smtp server, authentication
> info, etc). It is supposed to send the email.
>
> Signature is like this (semi java code, not implemented yet):
>
> protected boolean sendEmail(Collection<String> recipients, HashTable
> config);
>
> Now, I'd really like to be able to test this without having to
> actually send the email [. . .]

I can think of a few options, but the simplest might be to just call the
method in your test and catch an expected MessagingException that would
indicate that the method worked all but for the actual transport.  But for
this to work, the mail service provider would have to throw a useful
exception that tells you that the send failed specifically because the mail
server wasn't accessible.

Another option is an abstract factory for getting different impls of the
class implementing this method (Template Method pattern), which differ only
in that one actually sends the message and the other fakes it.

Scott Stirling
Framingham, MA
